Chapter 32: The Council Divided

Late February 1432
Toledo Cathedral Chapter House

The Abbott of Valladolid's words hung in the heavy air. Several bishops shifted uncomfortably—his frank acknowledgment of papal corruption made them uneasy even as they knew it to be true.

Bishop de Isorna stood abruptly, his chair scraping against the stone floor. "This is precisely what Basel wants—to undermine faith in the Holy Father by cataloging every human failing! Yes, popes are men. Yes, they sin. But that does NOT give bishops the right to place themselves ABOVE the successor of Saint Peter!" His voice echoed off the vaulted ceiling. "The Council of Constance was an emergency measure during schism—nothing more. Basel perverts it into permanent revolution!"

Archbishop Gutiérrez raised both hands, his voice cutting through the rising murmurs. "Brothers. We are not here to relitigate church history. His Majesty has asked us a direct question: Should Castile send representatives to Basel?" He turned to face you fully. "And more importantly—if we do, what position should they take?"

The room fell silent. All eyes fixed on you.

My dear bishops and men of the cloth, I have summoned you to discuss what we as good christians should do.


You all know that I take matters of faith very serious, and that my meeting and relationship with the late pope has shaped me more than anything. When I committed everything to the church, the Hussite heresy was exactly one of the reasons why I felt like the church needed a faithful kingdom to represent it's spiritual interests in the material world.


I have since then seem much of the world. I have seen justice and cruelty. Honour and betrayal. I have seen my Isabel suffer more than anyone ever should while she is the lord's most devout and innocent follower. I have fought against the Moors and I have also found some who are more honourable than some of those who claim to be christian. Do not misunderstand me, my zeal to drive out Islam has never been stronger. But in some cases claiming to be a good christian is simply not enough.


My first instinct is to lead the armies of Castille against Prague as soon as we are done in Grenada. I will lead them myself and make sure the armies of Christ are not defeated. But we must be absolutely sure and go to war for the right reasons.


That is why I have summoned you. This council of Basel seems like an important event and my first instict is that we should at least be present. But maybe I am wrong. Maybe my first instinct is wrong. What should we do?

Bishop de Cartagena refers to his documents. "The Hussites presented four demands at Prague, which have become known as the Four Articles. They are the minimum terms the Hussites will accept for any reconciliation with the Church."

He reads carefully: "First, free preaching of the Word of God. The Hussites demand that priests be allowed to preach without episcopal censorship or restriction. They claim the Gospel should be available to all people in their own language."

"Heresy!" Bishop de León explodes. "Unchecked preaching leads directly to error! This is how Hus himself corrupted Bohemia—standing in his pulpit spreading poison without proper authority!"

De Cartagena continues: "Second, communion in both kinds—both bread and wine—for all laypeople, not just priests. Currently, as Your Majesty knows, the laity receives only the bread. The Hussites demand the chalice as well."

Bishop de Ávila shakes his head vehemently. "This questions the Church's authority to determine the sacraments! If we concede this, what next? Every heretic will demand changes to sacred rites!"

"Third," de Cartagena reads on, his voice growing quieter, "poverty of clergy and expropriation of church property. The Hussites demand that priests and bishops own no temporal possessions, living in apostolic poverty. All church lands and wealth should be seized and redistributed."

A shocked silence fills the room. Several bishops exchange alarmed glances. The Abbott of Valladolid speaks grimly: "This is not reform—this is destruction. They would strip the Church of the very resources needed to carry out its mission. How would monasteries function? How would cathedrals be maintained? How would the poor be fed?"

"Finally," de Cartagena concludes, "the fourth article: punishment of mortal sins regardless of rank. They demand that all public mortal sins—especially simony, usury, and clerical unchastity—be punished equally whether committed by bishop or peasant. No one is exempt."

Bishop de Isorna stands slowly. "Your Majesty, you see now what Basel negotiates with? The first article undermines church authority over preaching. The second questions our control of the sacraments. The third would destroy the Church as an institution. The fourth..." he pauses, "the fourth sounds reasonable in principle, but in practice means secular authorities investigating and punishing clergy. It strips the Church of its independent jurisdiction."

But the Bishop of Palencia speaks up, his young voice uncertain but thoughtful: "Though... Your Majesty... the fourth article. Is it entirely wrong? Should a bishop who commits simony escape punishment because of his rank? Should a priest who keeps a concubine be exempt from consequences?"

"That is for the Church to handle internally!" Bishop de Ávila snaps. "Not for heretics to dictate, and certainly not for secular courts to enforce!"

Archbishop Gutiérrez observes the debate, then turns to you. "Your Majesty, Basel's negotiations with the Hussites focus on these four articles. The question is whether any compromise is possible. Can the Church concede any of these demands without betraying fundamental doctrine? Or must all four be rejected entirely, even if it means continued war?"

He pauses meaningfully. "Five crusades have failed. The Hussites defeated every army sent against them, including the one Cardinal Cesarini led last year. Basel believes negotiation might succeed where military force has failed. But many—" he gestures to the conservative bishops, "—believe negotiating with heretics legitimizes heresy itself."

The room waits to hear your thoughts on these demands.
